name: Corrgenn

attributes.attribute: poetry of Irish place-names transcribed in the 12th century
son of the god Dagda who was killed by Coincheann for seducing his wife
famous location where Coincheann finally buried the body of Áed Minbhrec

sources: Monaghan, Patricia. The Encyclopedia of Celtic Mythology and Folklore. Checkmark Books, 2008.
text: Irish hero Corrgenn, also known as Coincheann, is featured in The Dindshenchas, a collection of poetry that transcribes Irish place-names from the 12th century. According to the text, Coincheann was responsible for the death of Áed Minbhrec, the son of the god Dagda, who had seduced his wife. As punishment, Coincheann was ordered to bear the corpse on his back until he found a rock of equal size to bury it beneath. He fulfilled this sentence by leaving the body at Hillfort of Grianán Aileach.
